heading.title: Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 (NSW)
UNIFORM CIVIL PROCEDURE RULES 2005
PART 42 COSTS [rr 42.1–42.35]
DIVISION 3 OFFERS OF COMPROMISE [rr 42.13–42.17]

p.text: This Division applies to proceedings in respect of which an offer of compromise (the offer) is made under rule 20.26 with respect to a plaintiff’s claim (the claim).
[r 42.13 subst SI 259 of 2013 Sch 1[5], effective 7 June 2013]

heading.title: NOTES

level.toc-caption: [42.13.5] Special costs orders where judgment no less favourable than offer

p.text: Legislation cited in [42.13.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 20.25–20.32, r 42.14, r 42.15.

heading.title: Special costs orders where judgment no less favourable than offer

p.text: This Division complements the “offer of compromise” provisions of UCPR rr 20.25–20.32 . Its purpose is to encourage proper early settlement of proceedings. It provides for indemnity costs orders that operate from the day after the relevant offer, in favour of a party whose offer is no less favourable to the offer or than the final judgment amount. In so far as the rules potentially operate in favour of a defendant they constitute a significant exception to the general rule that costs follow the event. Because of the costs consequences for which it provides, legal practitioners have an obligation to consider realistically the application of r 42.14 and r 42.15 when advising parties to proceedings: Maitland Hospital v Fisher (No 2) (1992) 27 NSWLR 721 at 725; BC9201767 .

level.toc-caption: [42.13.7] Judgment including interest — whether no less favourable

p.text: Legislation cited in [42.13.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.14, r 42.15, r 42.15A, r 42.16.

heading.title: Judgment including interest — whether no less favourable

p.text: In determining whether the judgment is “no less favourable” for the purposes of r 42.14 (or "as or less favourable” in r 42.15 or “as or more favourable” in r 42.15A ) only the amount of interest or damages by way of interest as relates to the period before the offer of compromise was made is taken into account: UCPR r 42.16 . Interest must therefore be taken into account in determining the amount to be offered in an offer of compromise, but it is not necessary to make provision for interest for the period after the offer is made.

heading.title: Offer must comply with the rules

p.text: The offer must comply with UCPR r 20.26 in order to attract operation of the costs rules contained in this Division. See the discussion at [20.26.5] .

level.toc-caption: [42.13.12] Claims and offers with non monetary terms — whether judgment no less favourable

p.text: Legislation cited in [42.13.12] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 42.14, 42.15.

heading.title: Claims and offers with non monetary terms — whether judgment no less favourable

p.text: The “no less favourable” criterion may be difficult to apply to claims and offers containing non monetary terms: Hosokawa Micron International Inc v Fortune (1989) 14 IPR 605 (claim for damages and injunction). Another instance of potential difficulty arises where a monetary offer includes other terms. An offer containing a condition to be satisfied within a reasonable period after acceptance of this offer is not uncertain and will take effect as an offer of compromise for the purposes of rr 42.14 and 42.15 : Whitehouse Properties Pty Ltd v Bond Brewing (NSW) Ltd (1992) 28 NSWLR 17 (offer conditional on surrender of possession). An offer of compromise made to one party may be expressed to be conditional on the acceptance of another offer made to a third party: Oxlade v Gosbridge Pty Ltd (No 2) [1999] NSWCA 165; BC9903593 . But, an offer which includes a term that the offer or any settlement should not be disclosed may not be an offer within the terms of r 20.26: Australian Volunteer Coastguard Assn Inc v Thompson (SC(NSW), Macready M, No 3644/91, 16 December 1994, unreported, BC9403522) at 5. Conditional offers of this kind have been considered in the context of offers made in Calderbank letters (see [42.13.25] ). If the offer is subject to some non monetary condition, such as requirements for an apology or release, proper exercise of the general costs discretion will involve the court in considering the reasonableness of the condition, and whether or not the judgment result was, in substance, more favourable than the offer: Magenta Nominees Pty Ltd v Richard Ellis (WA) Pty Ltd (Fed C of A, Full Court, WAG66/94, 29 August 1995, unreported, BC9506519) (requirement for release and confidentiality special costs order made); Timms v Clift [1998] 2 Qd R 100; BC9701026 (defamation offer requiring apology special costs order); Assaf v Skalkos [2000] NSWSC 935; BC200006008 and Skalkos v Assaf (No 2) [2002] NSWCA 236; BC200204574 (defamation apology refused indemnity costs ordered).

level.toc-caption: [42.13.13] Offer must be a true compromise

p.text: Legislation cited in [42.13.13] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 20.26, UCPR r 20.26(2).

heading.title: Offer must be a true compromise

p.text: The basic purpose of the offer of compromise procedure is to encourage genuine compromise of proceedings, by specifying the conditions in which special costs orders may be made. Consistent with this purpose, both under the present rules and under the general law (see [42.13.25] ) the offer must involve “a real and genuine element of compromise”: Herning v GWS Machinery Pty Ltd (No 2) [2005] NSWCA 375; BC200509665 (Calderbank letter); Anderson Group Pty Ltd v Tynan Motors Pty Ltd (No 2) [2006] NSWCA 120; BC200603504 ; Leichhardt Municipal Council v Green [2004] NSWCA 341; BC200406280 . Consequently, where a plaintiff's offer is in substance merely a demand for payment of the full amount claimed, or a formal offer “designed simply to trigger the entitlement to indemnity costs”, wholly exceptional circumstances would be required to justify an indemnity costs order: Tickell v Trifleska Pty Ltd (1990) 25 NSWLR 353 at 355 ; Hobartville Stud Pty Ltd v Union Insurance Co Ltd (1991) 25 NSWLR 358 at 368 . Conversely, a defendant’s “offer” that involves dismissal of the claim and payment of the defendant’s costs also lacks the necessary element of compromise: Shorten v David Hurst Constructions Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 609; BC200804589 at [6] . Even a defendant’s offer to bear its own costs, or contribute only a trivial proportion of the claim, may lack the element of compromise necessary to comply with UCPR r 20.26 : Leichhardt Municipal Council v Green [2004] NSWCA 341; BC200406280 at [31]–[37] ; Herning v GWS Machinery Pty Ltd (No 2) [2005] NSWCA 375; BC200509665 at [4]–[5] .

The interpretation that a complying offer must involve “genuine” compromise posits a factual and impressionistic enquiry that involves some tension with the literal wording of the rules. The rules specifically contemplate an offer for a verdict for the defendant, and at least implicitly contemplate that such an offer by a defendant could involve the requisite compromise: UCPR r 20.26(2) . The rules also permit special costs orders where the offer is only “as favourable” as, or “no more/ less favourable” than the ultimate judgment. That permission necessarily extends to cases where there is either no difference, or only a marginal difference, between the offer terms and the final judgment. This tension can be seen in some of the cases referred to in [20.26.10] , [42.13.20] and [42.14.10] and in Manly Council v Byrne (No 2) [2004] NSWCA 227; BC200404750 at [20] (offer made on appeal to accept judgment without interest, genuine compromise). The way in which it is to be resolved is not entirely clear – as is illustrated by the differing views expressed in Uniting Church in Australia Property Trust (NSW) v Takacs (No 2) [2008] NSWCA 172; BC200806906 at [12] per Hodgson JA and [26]–[33] per Basten JA. Whilst a merely formal offer, involving no element of compromise, does not comply with the rules, the rules require neither a plaintiff nor a defendant to offer substantial amounts, as a pre-condition to the validity of their respective offers: Leichhardt Municipal Council v Green [2004] NSWCA 341; BC200406280 at [37]–[40] — distinguishing Singh v Singh (No 2) [2004] NSWSC 225; BC20040372 and McKerlie v NSW (No 2) [2000] NSWSC 1159; BC200007818 . The particular elements involved in a factual enquiry as to whether an offer involves a real element of “compromise” are discussed by Giles J in Hobartville Stud v Union Insurance Co (1991) 25 NSWLR 358 at 368 , and by Santow JA in Leichhardt Municipal Council v Green [2004] NSWCA 341; BC200406280 at [37]–[40] . However both that discussion, and the later consideration by Basten JA in Uniting Church in Australia Property Trust (NSW) v Takacs (No 2) [2008] NSWCA 172; BC200806906 at [23]–[28] reveal the uncertain nature of the distinction, for the purpose of the rules, between a genuine and a merely purported offer of compromise. See Prosperity Advisers Pty Ltd v Secure Enterprises Pty Ltd T/as Strathearn Insurance Brokers [2012] NSWCA 192; BC201204919 at [107]–[112] (offer of compromise of $10,000 on $340,000 claim was relevantly genuine given the strength of the case in light of the evidence — the offerer was giving something away — indemnity costs upheld).

Recognising the difficulty involved, some cases have proceeded on the basis that the contentious offer may be assumed to be valid, but the amount of the offer should nevertheless be taken into account in exercising the discretion to “order otherwise” and refuse the application for indemnity costs: Miwa Pty Ltd v Siantan Properties Pte Ltd (No 2) [2011] NSWCA 344; BC201108674 at [12]–[19] (rejection of a merely nominal compromise not unreasonable): Uniting Church in Australia Property Trust (NSW) v Takacs (No 2) [2008] NSWCA 172; BC200806906 at [12] (defendant’s $20,000 offer — wholly insufficient to meet substantial claim – plaintiff acted reasonably in pursuing proceedings). The general principles relevant to the exercise of the discretion to “order otherwise” are discussed in [20.27.15] . The concept of “unreasonable” rejection of offers is dealt with in [42.13.27].

level.toc-caption: [42.13.15] Formal offers are exclusive of costs

p.text: Legislation cited in [42.13.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 20.26(2).

heading.title: Formal offers are exclusive of costs

p.text: It is common for parties to negotiate settlement on terms that are inclusive of costs. But UCPR r 20.26(2) provides that a formal offer of compromise is exclusive of costs, unless it offers a verdict for a defendant and states that the parties are to bear their own costs. If a defendant's formal offer of payment purported to include costs, an accepting plaintiff may still be entitled to recover their costs of the proceedings — at least if the offer involved a virtual capitulation by the defendant: Thiess Contractors Pty Ltd v SCI Operations Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Rogers CJ, 21 September 1990, unreported). Because a payment offer inclusive of costs would not comply with the offer of compromise rules that entitlement could not arise from the special costs rules themselves: Associated Confectionery (Aust) Ltd v Mineral and Chemical Trades Pty Ltd (1991) 25 NSWLR 349 . Instead, the court would be required to consider the contentious application of the principles in Calderbank v Calderbank [1975] 3 All ER 333; [1976] Fam 93 at 106; [1975] 3 WLR 586 to offers expressed to be “inclusive of costs”: see [42.13.25] .

level.toc-caption: [42.13.20] Appeal proceedings — pre trial and appeal offers

p.text: Legislation cited in [42.13.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 51.1, r 51.48, r 51.49.

heading.title: Appeal proceedings — pre trial and appeal offers

p.text: The rules apply to proceedings in the Court of Appeal. In applying the rule to proceedings in the Court of Appeal the parties retain their ordinary description as plaintiff and defendant — despite the special usage otherwise provided for in UCPR r 51.1 : Suresh v Jacon Industries Pty Ltd (No 2) [2005] NSWCA 270; BC200506075 ; Anderson Group Pty Ltd v Tynan Motors Pty Ltd (No 2) [2006] NSWCA 120; BC200603504 at [17] (in relation to the application of the UCPR); Ambulance Service of NSW v Worley (No 2) (2006) 67 NSWLR 719; [2006] NSWCA 236; BC200606639 at [21] ; Maitland Hospital v Fisher (No 2) (1992) 27 NSWLR 721 at 724 and 727; BC9201767 ; Nominal Defendant v Gardikiotis (No 2) (NSWCA, Priestley, Meagher and Sheller JJA, 23 June 1994, unreported, BC9404984); Uniting Church in Australia Property Trust (NSW) v Takacs (No 2) [2008] NSWCA 172; BC200806906 at [16], [34] . See also UCPR r 51.48.

heading.title: Relevance of pre-trial offers

p.text: A pre-trial offer of compromise continues to have effect for the purposes of the present rules notwithstanding that the time for its acceptance elapsed well before the conclusion of the proceedings: Ettingshausen v Australian Consolidated Press Ltd (1995) 38 NSWLR 404 . Once the offer has been made, and not accepted within time, it remains relevant to the exercise of the costs discretion at the trial, on any appeal, and even in relation to the costs of a subsequent retrial: Ettingshausen v Australian Consolidated Press Ltd (1995) 38 NSWLR 404 (plaintiff entitled to indemnity costs from the date of the offer of compromise notwithstanding a retrial on quantum and a new, reduced award following the retrial); Lee v Kennedy [2001] NSWCA 8; BC200100197 ; Evatt v Nationwide News Pty Ltd (No 2) [1999] NSWCA 143; BC9902713 . Rebenta Pty Ltd v Wise (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 334; BC200909365 at [12]–[14] (successful defendant — offers at trial and on appeal — trial offer relevant to costs incurred before appeal offer lodged); see also UCPR r 51.49 (Court of Appeal may have regard to any offer of compromise made in the court below).

heading.title: Relevance of the “follow the event” principle

p.text: Nevertheless, the rule that costs ordinarily follow the event is also relevant and requires particular consideration in relation to the outcome of an appeal: Anderson Group Pty Ltd v Tynan Motors Pty Ltd (No 2) [2006] NSWCA 120; BC200603504 ; Maricic v Dalma Formwork (Australia) Pty Ltd (No 2) [2006] NSWCA 237; BC200606640 at [20] . A “successful” appellant may be awarded the costs of the appeal (notwithstanding a pre-trial offer) in a range of circumstances — including:
where a plaintiff's appeal succeeds on liability and the issue of damages is remitted: Maricic v Dalma Formwork (Australia) Pty Ltd (No 2) (2006) 67 NSWLR 237; [2006] NSWCA 237; BC200606640 ;

where a plaintiff's appeal results in a final judgment — even though less favourable than the defendant's pre-trial offer: Moore v Woodforth (2003) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-686; [2003] NSWCA 9; BC200300214 ; Moore v Woodforth (No 2) [2003] NSWCA 46; BC200301140 ;

where a defendant's appeal reduces the judgment — but not below the amount of the plaintiff's pre-trial offer of compromise: Fotheringham v Fotheringham (No 2) (1999) 46 NSWLR 194 (plaintiff respondent ordered to pay the appellant's costs); Commercial Union Assurance Co of Australia Ltd v Pelosi (No 2) (NSWCA, Handley, Shelley and Powell JJA, 27 February 1996, unreported) .

Between these extremes a substantially successful defendant appellant may recover (part of) the costs of an appeal, even though the substituted judgment still exceeds the defendant's pre-trial offer (Diamond v Simpson (No 2) [2003] NSWCA 78; BC200301668 ), be left to bear only its own costs of the appeal, or be ordered to pay the respondent's costs on the ordinary basis. South Sydney Council v Morris (No 3) [2001] NSWCA 200; BC200103425 (District Court plaintiff respondent awarded non-indemnity costs of the appeal — District Court cost rules did not apply to the appeal). Even an unsuccessful appellant may limit the scope of indemnity costs order resulting from an offer of compromise made at trial: Patrick Stevedores (No 1) Pty Ltd v Vaughan [2002] NSWCA 422 ; BC200208052 (award of indemnity costs only after second offer made in the appeal proceedings — appeal involved novel point and reasonable to test the judgment).

heading.title: Desirability of specific offer in appeal proceedings

p.text: UCPR r 51.49 permits the Court of Appeal to have regard to any offer of compromise made in the court below. But the permission thus conferred still has to be exercised in the light of the specific adaption (in UCPR r 51.48 ) of the offer of compromise rules to proceedings in the Court of Appeal: see Regency Media Pty Ltd v AAV Australia Pty Ltd [2009] NSWCA 368; BC200910207 at [37] ff. Consequently many cases have pointed out that it is highly desirable that parties to appeal proceedings make specific offers related to the appeal proceedings — rather than relying upon the uncertain effect of pre-trial offers:
Brymount Pty Ltd (t/as Watson Toyota) v Cummins (No 2) [2005] NSWCA 69; BC200501363 at [28] (Calderbank offer — costs followed the event — no order for indemnity costs);
Baresic v Slingshot Holdings Pty Ltd (No 2) [2005] NSWCA 160; BC200503069 at [20]–[21] (Calderbank offer — successful appellant awarded costs on a party party basis);
Stuart Pty Ltd v Condor Commercial Insulation Pty Ltd (No 2) [2006] NSWCA 379; BC200610813 at [8]–[12] (offer of compromise — no indemnity costs);
Grace v Thomas Street Café Pty Ltd (No 2) [2008] NSWCA 72; BC200802888 at [33] (no further offer made following first instance decision);
Encyclopaedia Britannica Australia Ltd v Campbell (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 335; BC200911103 (offer of compromise at trial, not renewed on appeal — no indemnity costs on appeal);
Regency Media Pty Ltd v AAV Australia Pty Ltd [2009] NSWCA 368; BC200910207 (no offer of compromise in the Court of Appeal proceedings — no basis for making a special order for the costs of appeal);

Miwa Pty Ltd v Siantan Properties Pte Ltd (No 2) [2011] NSWCA 344; BC201108674 at [12]–[19] (rejection of a merely nominal pre trial Calderbank offer — not unreasonable — plaintiff offeror failed at trial, succeeded on appeal).

heading.title: Calderbank letters — admissibility and form

p.text: Correspondence containing an offer to settle the claim may be admissible on the determination of costs questions even if there has been no formal offer of compromise under the rules: Jones v Bradley (No 2) [2003] NSWCA 258; BC200305520 at [13] (the absence of a formal offer is a relevant, but not determinative, consideration). The correspondence may be admissible either under s 131(2)(h) of the Evidence Act 1995: Nobrega v Trustees for the Roman Catholic Church for the Archdiocese of Sydney (No 2) [1999] NSWCA 133; BC9902730 ; or under the general law, if it substantially complies with the form suggested by Cairns LJ in Calderbank v Calderbank [1975] 3 All ER 333; [1976] Fam 93 at 106 (that is, the offer is expressed to be without prejudice save as to costs).

heading.title: Calderbank letters — offers “inclusive of costs”

p.text: There have been differing views about the relevance, and significance, of settlement offers made on an “inclusive of costs” basis. The two main reasons advanced for disregarding “inclusive of costs” offers are the difficulties for (i) the courts in determining whether a judgment amount is no less favourable than an unaccepted offer and (ii) an offeree in assessing the real value of the offer. Those reasons have prevailed in some cases where “costs inclusive” offers have been regarded as irrelevant to the exercise of the costs discretion: Associated Confectionery (Aust) Ltd v Mineral and Chemical Traders Pty Ltd (1991) 25 NSWLR 349 ; Smallacombe v Lockyer Investment Co Pty Ltd (1993) 42 FCR 97 at 102; 114 ALR 568 ; Hanave Pty Ltd v LFOT Pty Ltd [1998] FCA 1429; BC9805973 ; Dr Martens Australia Pty Ltd v Figgins Holdings Pty Ltd (No 2) [2000] FCA 602; BC200002244 at [24] (inclusive offers irrelevant); Baulderstone Hornibrook Engineering Pty Ltd v Gordian Runoff Ltd [2006] NSWSC 583; BC200604424 at [40] . But the former reason has no persuasive force where the final judgment substantially exceeds the offer. The second reason has little force in the case of a defendant’s offer – because the plaintiff should be well able to make a reasonable estimate of the costs they have incurred: Elite Protective Personnel Pty Ltd v Salmon [2007] NSWCA 322; BC200709738 at [144]–[145] per Basten JA. Accordingly, the better view is that “inclusive of costs” offers may properly inform the exercise of the costs discretion and may, depending on the particular circumstances, permit an award of indemnity costs: Elite Protective Personnel Pty Ltd v Salmon [2007] NSWCA 322; BC200709738 at [5]–[7] per Mason P and at [133]–[147] per Basten JA; MT Assocs Pty Ltd v Aqua-Max Pty Ltd [2000] VSC 163; BC200002334 (inclusive offer relevant); Tinyow v Lee [2006] NSWCA 247; BC200606890 at [7]–[10] . The actual significance of an inclusive offer will depend on the particular circumstances. If the final judgment amount (excluding interest) only marginally exceeds the unaccepted inclusive offer, it will be difficult for the offeror to show, and the court should not entertain a detailed assessment to establish, that the judgment amount exceeds the damages component of the offer: Elite Protective Personnel Pty Ltd v Salmon [2007] NSWCA 322; BC200709739 at [5]–[7] per Mason P and at [145] and [150] per Basten JA.

level.toc-caption: [42.13.26] Calderbank letters — costs consequences of unreasonable rejection

heading.title: Calderbank letters — costs consequences of unreasonable rejection

p.text: The offer may justify a special order for costs, including an order for costs on an indemnity basis, if the final judgment is no more favourable than the terms of the offer: Singleton v Macquarie Broadcasting Holdings Ltd (1991) 24 NSWLR 103 at 108; Beregold Pty Ltd v Mitsopoulos (NSWSC, Cole J, No 55013/90, 20 November 1992, unreported, BC9201471); Macquarie Bank Ltd v National Mutual Life Assn of Australasia Ltd (NSWSC, Cole J, 27 July 1994, unreported, BC9402833); Wallace v Baulkham Hills Smash Repairs Pty Ltd (No 2) (NSWSC, 21 August 1995, Young J, unreported, BC9505364). Some cases have held that there was a presumption in favour of awarding “post offer” costs on an indemnity basis if the offer was reasonable: Multicon Engineering Pty Ltd v Federal Airports Corp (1996) 138 ALR 425 (Multicon); Naomi Marble and Granite Pty Ltd v FAI General Insurance Co Ltd (No 2) [1999] 1 Qd R 518; BC9800777 .

The settled principle in NSW is that there is no such presumption. A Calderbank type of offer will not justify an indemnity costs order unless it embodied a compromise (see [42.13.13] above) and its rejection was unreasonable: Jones v Bradley (No 2) [2003] NSWCA 258; BC200305520 at [13] ; Miwa Pty Ltd v Siantan Properties Pte Ltd (No 2) [2011] NSWCA 344; BC201108674 at [8]; SMEC Testing Services Pty Ltd v Campbelltown City Council [2000] NSWCA 323 ; BC200006070 at [37] ; Nobrega v Trustees for the Roman Catholic Church for the Archdiocese of Sydney (No 2) [1999] NSWCA 133; BC9902730 ; LMI Australasia Pty Ltd v Baulderstone Hornibrook Pty Ltd [2003] NSWCA 74; BC200301670 ; Skalkos v Assaf (No 2) [2002] NSWCA 236; BC200204574 ; Leichhardt Municipal Council v Green [2004] NSWCA 341; BC200406280 at [46] and [47] (offer by a successful defendant); Russell v Edwards (No 2) [2006] NSWCA 52; BC200602115 at [6]–[7] ; Commonwealth v Gretton [2008] NSWCA 117; BC200803965 at [44], [105] and [117] (unaccepted offer — offer exclusive of offeree’s unquantified interlocutory costs liability — indemnity costs refused); Penrith Rugby League Club Ltd (t/as Cardiff Panthers) v Elliot (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 356; BC200909906 (unsuccessful plaintiff/respondent — offer of compromise reasonable in the circumstances — genuine and sufficient time specified for acceptance — costs of trial payable on indemnity basis). That principle, though arguably similar in substance to Multicon , above (see Jones v Bradley (No 2) , above, at [9]; Black v Tomislav Lipovac BHNF Maria Lipovac (1998) 217 ALR 386; [1998] FCA 699; BC9802571 at [218] ), emphasises the width of the discretion and the unusual nature of an order for indemnity costs.

heading.title: Calderbank letters — "unreasonable" rejection

p.text: The factors relevant to determining whether the rejection of an offer was “unreasonable” include (i) the stage of the proceedings, (ii) the time provided for acceptance, (iii) the extent of the compromise, (iv) the offeree’s prospects of success, and (v) the clarity of the offer, and whether or not it conveyed an intention to rely on the offer in an application for indemnity costs: Hazeldene’s Chicken Farm Pty Ltd v Victorian Work Cover Authority (No 2) (2005) 13 VR 435; [2005] VSCA 298; BC200510663 ; Miwa Pty Ltd v Siantan Properties Pte Ltd (No 2) [2011] NSWCA 344; BC201108674 at [12]–[19] (rejection of a merely nominal pre trial Calderbank offer — not unreasonable — plaintiff offeror failed at trial, succeeded on appeal). The width of the discretionary considerations relevant to the “unreasonableness” of rejecting a Calderbank offer is illustrated by the potential relevance of considerations other than the mere comparison of the settlement amount with that of the final judgment. A party who rejects a settlement offer after being warned of a challenge to evidence that is subsequently found to be false, may be held to have acted unreasonably: Blagojevch v Australian Industrial Relations Commission (2000) 98 FCR 45; 172 ALR 611; BC200001870 . If the offer is subject to some non-monetary condition, such as requirements for an apology or release, proper exercise of the discretion will involve the court considering the reasonableness of the condition, and whether or not the judgment result was, in substance, more favourable than the offer: Magenta Nominees Pty Ltd v Richard Ellis (WA) Pty Ltd (FCA, Full Court, WAG66/94, 29 August 1995, unreported, BC9506519) (requirement for release and confidentiality — special costs order made); Timms v Clift [1998] 2 Qd R 100; BC9701026 (defamation — offer requiring apology — special costs order); Assaf v Skalkos [2000] NSWSC 935; BC200006008 and Skalkos v Assaf (No 2) [2002] NSWCA 236; BC200204574 (defamation — apology refused — indemnity costs ordered).
Examples of situations where rejection of the offer have not been characterised as unreasonable, and where indemnity costs orders have been refused include the following:

Where the amount offered was held not to involve any significant compromise: Miwa Pty Ltd v Siantan Properties Pte Ltd (No 2) [2011] NSWCA 344; BC201108674 at [12]–[19] (rejection of a merely nominal pre trial Calderbank offer — not unreasonable — plaintiff offeror failed at trial, succeeded on appeal); see also Regency Media Pty Ltd v AAV Australia Pty Ltd [2009] NSWCA 368; BC200910207 at [32].

Where it was not unreasonable to reject the offer: Tati v Stonewall Hotel Pty Ltd (No 2) [2012] NSWCA 124; BC201202973 (offer to forego an existing entitlement to costs — arguable grounds of appeal — no indemnity costs);

Where a party succeeded at trial on a case that significantly changed after the offer was made: Rolls Royce Industrial Power (Pacific) Ltd v James Hardie and Co Pty Ltd (2001) 53 NSWLR 626; [2001] NSWCA 461; BC200108080 at [95]–[99] ; Wakeford v Ellis (NSWSC, McLaughlin M, No 1487/96, 7 May 1998, unreported, BC9804384).

Where the offer was only open for 5 days and acceptance was conditional on the release of claims in unrelated proceedings: Baulderstone Hornibrook Engineering Pty Ltd v Gordian Runoff Ltd [2006] NSWSC 583; BC200604424 at [73] , [74].
Where the offer was made after commencement of the trial and was only open for 7 days: Ng v Chong [2005] NSWSC 385; BC200502550 at [13] , [14].

Where the offer was only open for a period significantly shorter than the acceptance period applicable to formal offers of compromise and expired before the offeree had the necessary evidence to assess the reasonableness of the offer: Chint Australasia Pty Ltd v Cosmoluce Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 768; BC200807181 ; Elite Protective Personnel Pty Ltd v Salmon [2007] NSWCA 322; BC200709738 at [117] (additional evidence served with the offer).
Where the offer expired before the offeree could obtain a required third party approval: Green v CGU Insurance Ltd [2008] NSWSC 929; BC200807973 (liquidator requiring creditor approval).

Where there is sufficient ambiguity in the offer: Lahoud v Lahoud [2011] NSWSC 1186; BC201108014 (reasonable not to accept the offer — parties had been in very heated litigious dispute for many years — ambiguity as to the terms and the wording of the offer).

heading.title: Disclosure of offers

p.text: A party is only permitted to tender “without prejudice” communications in the form of offers of compromise in the express circumstances set out in the rules: see r 20.30(3) of the UCPR: Macplan Logistic Systems Pty Ltd v Baxter Healthcare Pty Ltd (1996) 39 NSWLR 324 at 325 or where allowed under s 131(2)(h) of the Evidence Act 1995: Marks v GIO Australia Holdings Ltd (No 2) (1996) 66 FCR 128; 137 ALR 579 at 584–5 ; Bruinsma v Menczer (1995) 40 NSWLR 716 ; Van Doore by his Tutor the Protective Cmr v Mendez (No 2) (NSWSC, Dunford J, No 13772/90, 30 June 1997, unreported, BC9702746). Accordingly, evidence of an offer of compromise is not admissible on a contested interlocutory application for security for costs: Macplan Logistic Systems, above. See also s 131 of the Evidence Act 1995.

heading.title: Land and Environment Court

p.text: This division does not apply to the following classes of proceedings in the Land and Environment Court: Class 1 (environmental planning and protection appeals), Class 2 (local government and miscellaneous appeals and applications) and Class 3 (land tenure, valuation, ratings and compensation matters) — other than (a) ss 19(a) , (c) , (c1) , (e) , (e2) , (e3) , (f) , (f1) or (g) or 40 of the Land and Environment Act 1979; (b) ss 179 , 181 , 677 or 730 of the Local Government Act 1993, or (c) s 44 of the Fisheries Management Act 1994: see Sch 1 to UCPR. It does apply to proceedings in class 4 (environmental planning and protection and development contract civil enforcement) of the Land and Environment Court: see also Sch 1 of the UCPR.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.13A] r 42.13A Where offer accepted and no provision for costs

leg:heading.title: Where offer accepted and no provision for costs

p.text: This rule applies if the offer:
is accepted by the offeree, and
does not make provision for costs in respect of the claim.

If the offer proposed a judgment in favour of the plaintiff in respect of the claim, the plaintiff is entitled to an order against the defendant for the plaintiff’s costs in respect of the claim, assessed on the ordinary basis up to the time when the offer was made.

If the offer proposed a judgment in favour of the defendant in respect of the claim (including a dismissal of a summons or a statement of claim), the defendant is entitled to an order against the plaintiff for the defendant’s costs in respect of the claim, assessed on the ordinary basis up to the time when the offer was made.
[r 42.13A subst SI 259 of 2013 Sch 1[5], effective 7 June 2013]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.14] r 42.14 Where offer not accepted and judgment no less favourable to plaintiff (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 22; DCR Part 39A, rule 25)

leg:heading.title: Where offer not accepted and judgment no less favourable to plaintiff (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 22; DCR Part 39A, rule 25)

p.text: This rule applies if the offer is made by the plaintiff, but not accepted by the defendant, and the plaintiff obtains an order or judgment on the claim no less favourable to the plaintiff than the terms of the offer.
[subr (1) am SI 259 of 2013 Sch 1[6], effective 7 June 2013]
Unless the court orders otherwise, the plaintiff is entitled to an order against the defendant for the plaintiff’s costs in respect of the claim:
assessed on the ordinary basis up to the time from which those costs are to be assessed on an indemnity basis under paragraph (b), and
assessed on an indemnity basis:
if the offer was made before the first day of the trial, as from the beginning of the day following the day on which the offer was made, and
if the offer was made on or after the first day of the trial, as from 11 am on the day following the day on which the offer was made.

heading.title: NOTES

level.toc-caption: [42.14.5] The scope of the recoverable costs

heading.title: The scope of the recoverable costs

p.text: The term “plaintiff's costs in respect of the claim” has a wide meaning. The costs of all interlocutory proceedings are recoverable under the present rule unless they are merely collateral to the principal proceedings: see generally r 42.7 and the accompanying notes. Thus the costs of an interlocutory application seeking an extension of a limitation period were held to be incurred in respect of the plaintiff's claim for damages and prima facie entitled the plaintiff to recover the costs of the application for extension of time: McLean v Commonwealth (NSWSC, Sperling J, No 21250/95, 22 August 1996, unreported, BC9603721).

level.toc-caption: [42.14.7] Costs limits in personal injury proceedings

heading.title: Costs limits in personal injury proceedings

p.text: Sections 338 to 341 of the Legal Profession Act 2004 potentially limit the amount of costs that may be awarded against a party in personal injury proceedings where the damages awarded are less than the relevant prescribed amount. That limit does not apply to restrict the award of indemnity costs where a plaintiff has obtained a judgment amount that is no less favourable than their complying offer of compromise under UCPR r 20.20: see Shellharbour City Council v Johnson (No 2) 67 NSWLR 308; [2006] NSWCA 114; BC200605024 at [34]–[40].

heading.title: Unless the court otherwise orders

p.text: Although the rule confers a discretion to otherwise order, a “successful” offeror has a right to a special costs order under the rules: Hillier v Sheather (1995) 36 NSWLR 414; BC9504564 . That right exists even where the offeror has made a subsequent offer for a different amount. The question that arises in the exercise of the discretion to “otherwise order” is whether the offeree has any basis for denying the “successful” offeror's apparent entitlement under the rules: Marsland v Andjelic (No 2) (1993) 32 NSWLR 649; 18 MVR 379; BC9303925 ; State Authorities Superannuation Board v Property Estates (Qld) Pty Ltd (1991) 11 BCL 28; BC9102378 ; AWA Ltd v Daniels (t/as Deloitte Haskins & Sells) (NSWSC, Rogers CJ in Comm D, 8 October 1992, unreported, BC9201567). That question should be approached on the basis that sufficient circumstances will generally be required to justify a departure from the rule: Morgan v Johnson (1998) 44 NSWLR 578 at 581–2; BC9804556 per Mason P; Hillier v Sheather (1995) 36 NSWLR 414 at 422–3; BC9504564. Despite some variations of expression in the cases (see Caine v Lumley General Insurance Ltd (No 2) [2008] NSWCA 109; BC200803845 at [35]–[37] and compare Regency Media Pty Ltd v AAV Australia Pty Ltd [2009] NSWCA 368; BC200910207 at [15]) the exercise of the discretion conferred by the rules to “otherwise order” does not require exceptional circumstances: see Barakat v Bazdarova [2012] NSWCA 140; BC201203248 at [42]–[49] per Tobias AJA (Bathurst CJ and Whealy JA agreeing) (commenting on the existence of apparently conflicting decisions addressing the point).

heading.title: Factors not requiring refusal of a special costs order

p.text: Consistent with the general requirement for particular circumstances the following considerations have been held not to require refusal of an indemnity costs order under the present rule:

where the claim involved significant contingencies making it difficult to assess the reasonableness of the offer: Hillier v Sheather (NSWLR) at 423; Maitland Hospital v Fisher (No 2) (1992) 27 NSWLR 721; BC9201767 at 725 (Fisher);

where the judgment amount only marginally exceeded the amount of the offer: Fisher (difference of 2.5%); Connor v Hatgis (No 2) (NSWCA, Kirby P, Priestley and Powell JJA, 7 December 1995, unreported, BC9501810) (verdict of only $4000 more than the offer of compromise made over 2 years earlier); Houatchanthara v Bednarczyk (NSWCA, Clarke, Handley JJA and Santow AJA, No 40542/96, 14 October 1996, unreported, BC9604998) ($750 excess); Macquarie Radio Network Pty Ltd v Dent (No 2) [2007] NSWCA 339; BC200710315 (difference of 7%);
where the offeree was unaware of adverse material evidence: Morgan v Johnson (1998) 44 NSWLR 578 ; BC9804556 (adverse video surveillance film);

where it was objectively reasonable for the offeror to test the other party's claim: New South Wales Insurance Ministerial Corp v Reeve (1993) 42 NSWLR 100; South Eastern Area Health Service v King [2006] NSWCA 2; BC200600916 at [83] per Hunt AJA;

where the terms of the offer reflected a “walk away” proposal, but still reflected a genuine compromise in the circumstances: Melchior v Sydney Adventist Hospital Ltd (No 2) [2009] NSWSC 65; BC200901150 (real benefit in offer to bear costs already incurred).

heading.title: Factors justifying refusal of a special costs order

p.text: The special costs rules only apply if the unaccepted offer represents a genuine compromise. The issues to which that requirement gives rise – where the offer is only marginally or immaterially different from the final judgment – are discussed in [42.13.13] and [42.13.27]. If the special rules do potentially apply, it is sufficient reason to “otherwise order” if the party succeeds at trial on a case that significantly changed after the date of the offer: Fowdh v Fowdh (NSWCA, Full Court, No 40399/93, 4 November 1993, unreported, BC9302200) at [6] per Mahoney JA; Van Doore by his Tutor the Protective Cmr v Mendez (No 2) (NSWSC, Dunford J, No 13772/90, 30 June 1997, unreported, BC9702746); South Eastern Sydney Area Health Service v King (No 2) [2006] NSWCA 2; BC200600916 at [84]–[85] ; Rae v Beddison Corp Pty Ltd (No 2) [2009] NSWSC 178; BC200901717 at [43]–[44] (plaintiff succeeded at trial on a new point only advanced in final submissions); Nominal Defendant v Hawkins [2011] NSWCA 93; BC201103692 . Similarly, a successful plaintiff offeror may be refused costs under the present rule where the costs incurred are wholly disproportionate to the judgment amount and the proceedings were pursued for an extraneous (political) purpose: Jones v Sutton (No 2) [2005] NSWCA 203; BC200504148 . A successful offeror may be deprived of costs attributable to their own unreasonable conduct — for example by unreasonably contesting a particular issue: EDPI Pty Ltd v Rapdocs Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 195; BC200701292 .

heading.title: NOTES

level.toc-caption: [42.15.5] Judgment no more favourable than defendant's offer of compromise

p.text: Legislation cited in [42.15.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 42.15, 42.15A, r 42.16.

heading.title: Judgment no more favourable than defendant's offer of compromise

p.text: The effect of UCPR rr 42.15 and 42.15A is to qualify the operation of the general rule that costs follow the event and are assessed on the ordinary basis. The qualification is that where a defendant makes an offer of compromise, and the final judgment is not more favourable to the plaintiff, then the defendant will be entitled , on an indemnity basis, to the costs they incur after the date of the offer. As to the considerations relevant to proper comparison of the offer and the judgment, see [42.13.12] (dealing with non monetary terms and conditions) and [42.13.7] and UCPR r 42.16 (dealing with interest).

level.toc-caption: [42.15.10] Costs and the Motor Accidents Compensation Act 1999

p.text: Legislation cited in [42.15.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Motor Accidents Compensation Act 1999 Chapter 6, s 151, Section 152, s 153.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 42.15.

heading.title: Costs and the Motor Accidents Compensation Act 1999

p.text: Chapter 6 (ss 147–156) of the Motor Accidents Compensation Act in general, and s 151 in particular, regulate costs in proceedings under the MAC Act and does not permit the operation of rules of court such as UCPR r 42.15 : San v Rumble (No 2) (2007) 48 MVR 492; [2007] NSWCA 259; BC2000708156 at [15] and [70] (claimant failed before the assessor, the District Court, and the Court of Appeal after rejecting significant offers of compromise — UCPR 42.15 did not operate to entitle defendant to indemnity costs). Section 152 of the MAC Act provides that the rules of court apply in relation to costs where proceedings were not preceded by a Claims Assessment and Resolution Service assessment. Under s 153 the court can make an order which departs from the detailed provisions of the act only in an "exceptional case and for the avoidance of substantial injustice".

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.16] r 42.16 Costs with respect to interest (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 22; DCR Part 39A, rule 25; LCR Part 31A, rule 20)

leg:heading.title: Costs with respect to interest (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 22; DCR Part 39A, rule 25; LCR Part 31A, rule 20)

p.text: If a plaintiff obtains an order or judgment for the payment of a debt or damages and:
the amount payable under the order or for which judgment is given includes interest or damages in the nature of interest, or
the court, by a separate order, awards the plaintiff interest or damages in the nature of interest in respect of the amount,

then, for the purpose of determining the consequences as to costs referred to in rule 42.14, 42.15 or 42.15A, the court must disregard so much of the interest, or damages in the nature of interest, as relates to the period after the day on which the offer was made.
[subr (1) am Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[11], effective 6 July 2007]
For the purpose only of this rule, the court may be informed of the fact that the offer was made, and of the date on which it was made, but must not be informed of its terms.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 42.17] r 42.17 Miscellaneous (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 22(10) and (11); DCR Part 39A, rule 25; LCR Part 31A, rule 20)

leg:heading.title: Miscellaneous (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 22(10) and (11); DCR Part 39A, rule 25; LCR Part 31A, rule 20)

p.text: Before the court makes any order under rule 42.14 or 42.15, the party to whom the offer is made may request the party making the offer to satisfy the court that the party making the offer was at all material times willing and able to carry out the offer.

If the court is satisfied that the party making the offer was at all material times willing and able to carry out the offer, then, unless the court orders otherwise, the party making the request must pay such of the costs of the party to whom the request is made as have been occasioned by the request.
If the court is not satisfied that the party making the offer was at all material times willing and able to carry out the offer, then, unless the court orders otherwise:
rules 42.14 and 42.15 do not apply, and
the party to whom the request is made must pay the costs of the party making the request occasioned by the request.

Unless the court orders otherwise, any application for an order for costs under rule 42.14 or 42.15 must be made forthwith after the order or judgment giving rise to the entitlement to the order for costs is made or given.
